questions.question: Tell me about yourself.
questions.tip: Come prepared with a one-minute summary of your professional career— only touching on the personal if it had any effect on the professional.

answers.answer: I am a easy-going, loyal, dedicated, hard working employee in need of a job. All of my previous employers said I was their best worker...
I am a seasoned Retail Manager strong in developing training programs and loss prevention techniques that have resulted in huge revenue savings for my last employer...

I am a good listener who can usually read people well, at my last job retention rate of my hires was 20 percent above the department average. I'm playing golf lessons but am struggling to shoot less than 100...

questions.question: What is your greatest weakness?
questions.tip: Tell the interviewer about weakness you managed to improve during previous job. Turn negative into positive!

answers.answer: I tend to lose my patience with incompetent people
Being organized wasn't my strongest point, but I implemented a time management system that really helped my organization skills.
I'm not sure - probably my messiness, but I'm a quick learner and I do really good work.
I've learned to make my perfectionism work to my advantage at work. I am excellent at meeting deadlines.

questions.question: What is your greatest strength?
questions.tip: The best way to respond is to describe the skills and experience that directly correlate with the job you are applying for.

answers.answer: It must be my ability to work with many different people regardless of their race and color.
I pride myself on my customer service skills and my ability to resolve what may be difficult situations
I do good work. I'm fast, intelligent, competent, quick learner, creative...
When I'm working on a project I prefer to complete the project well ahead of schedule. Last year, I even earned a bonus for completing my reports one week ahead of time.

questions.question: How do you handle stress and pressure?
questions.tip: Show that you can deal with stress and please keep your stress relievers for yourself.

answers.answer: I find that when I'm under the pressure of a deadline, I can do some of my most creative work.
I am doing the things the best I can, and if I cannot handle it, I will ask help from my supervisor.
During a difficult financial period, I was able to satisfactorily negotiate repayment schedules with multiple vendors. I coordinated the team to get the schedule back on track
Stress has been real problem for me, but I found a cure. I often shoot squirrels with my rifle.

questions.question: How are you different from the competition?
questions.tip: Summarize your strengths as a candidate with an emphasis on any assets that might separate you from the typical applicant.

answers.answer: Of course, I am not aware of the other candidates but I believe they never created complex Excel macros to track seasonal variations in sales and expenses. It helped my department to save money.
I have no idea who you are competing with for this particular job so I can't answer this question with certanty. Feel free to cross-reference my resume with others.
Like I said before - I'm the best one for the job. I am great with people and a hard worker.
I am sure there are lots of talented people applying for such a position. However, given my unique background and experiences, I think I would be a strong candidate for this position

questions.question: What do you know about the company?
questions.tip: Do some research, prepare some bullet points, don't embarrass yourself!

answers.answer: In my research about this company I discovered that you had started out over 100 years ago as a small brick and mortar retailer in Center City
I know that this company is the number one widget wholesaler in the US, with a growing overseas presence in Europe and Asia.
I didn't actually do any research. I thought you are gonna tell me about this company.
Your company's products are the highest rated in the industry.

questions.question: Why do you want to work here?
questions.tip: The interviewer wants to know what interests you about the company and why you would like to work for this particular organization.

answers.answer: This seems like a really interesting place to work, with the variety of items that you offer and given today's job market it is the best job I could find.
The company is known for its commitment to the local community, and I would like the opportunity to participate in making this a better place to live.
well understand that this is a company on the way up. Your web site says the launch of several new products is imminent. I want be a part of this business as it grows
I want this job selling theater tickets because I'd be good at it. I'm good at speaking to people and handling cash. I would like a job with regular hours and I'm always on time.

questions.question: What is your dream job?
questions.tip: The key to answering is to convey your long-term interest in a high-level position, without overshadowing your interest in the job you’re applying for.

answers.answer: Well I always wanted to be CEO of Google but that's not happening any time soon so here we are...
I'm gonna say...This job obviously. Right?
My dream job will have to include elements of video and audio, as well as two-dimensional design. This is why I applied for this position...
I don’t necessarily have a specific job that I dream about. My dream job is to have a workplace that is welcoming and friendly, with ample growth opportunities

questions.question: Describe your ideal boss.
questions.tip: Think about the job you are interviewing for, and try to estimate how much management the employer will expect you to need

answers.answer: The best boss is a motivator who interacts with staff freely, never favors anyone and treats everybody fairly.
I learned a lot about organization from my last boss. I've always been an organized person, but I learned new ways to organize and mobilize the staff from him
Best boss is the one I can drink beer with after work. He should have a great sense of humor and be easy-going
I think my best boss must have these qualifications: team builder, good communicator. When making decisions for their subordinates, he should put himself in their shoes.

questions.question: What did you like or dislike about your previous job?
questions.tip: Don't be too negative. The reason is that you don't want the interviewer to think that you'll speak negatively about the new job or the company when you're ready to move on.

answers.answer: There was so much structure and rules to the place I worked at that I started to feel like a robot after a while.
I hated my job. My boss always had a pick on me and made me do hardest jobs. Also my coworkers were kind of dumb.
I liked being part of the company. Everything that I did was appreciated by everyone and I did not feel left out in any way.
I enjoyed the people I worked with and the friendly atmosphere. One of the reasons I left was that I did not felt challenged enough at the job.

questions.question: Why should we hire you?
questions.tip: Your answer to this question should be a concise “sales pitch” that explains what you have to offer the employer.

answers.answer: I can easily cope with new challenges, and interact effectively with people that I haven't worked with yet. I am also willing to go beyond expectations when it comes to work and being involved.
I have the 6 years of experience you’re looking for, a track record of successful projects, and proven expertise in agile development processes.
Well, I have all of the skills and experience that you’re looking for and I’m confident that I would be a superstar in this project management role
I'm the best one for the job and you are missing out if you don' hire me.

questions.question: Where do you see yourself 5 years from now?
questions.tip: Show that you want to keep learning. It is often advantageous to emphasize your interest in thoroughly mastering the initial position before moving on

answers.answer: In 5 years I want to have a good paying job, be happily married and have a few kids.
Within 5 years I would like to be recognized as an expert in terms of product knowledge and perhaps have been assigned some major national clients.
I am interested in all aspects of the retail market, and see myself in the long term spending some time working in a variety of roles
I'm not sure what I'll be doing, but I want to be making enough money to move from my parents house.

questions.question: What will you do if you don't get this position?
questions.tip: Show persistance, desire to grow and that you are not going to give up regardless of this interviews result.

answers.answer: You mean hypothetically? Well I wouldn't be suprised. This interview wasn't going so well anyway
I will feel disappointed, but I will work on my interviewing skills so I can do better at the next interview.
I will continue looking in this field for another position that will fit my schedule and goals.
I will probably lay low for a while. This job search is really stressful, I need some rest.

questions.question: What are your salary expectations?
questions.tip: Avoid giving a number. If forced to suggest make sure you are realistic and honest about your salary expectations

answers.answer: I have done my research and I know that your average employee has between $1000 and $1200. I will settle for $1200
I understand that positions similar to this one pay in the range of $1000 to $1200 in our region. Something in that range would be acceptable.
I'd like to postpone salary discussions until we are both sure I'm right for the job
I believe that $1500 would suffice considering my skills and experience. Yes it's a bit too much but I am worth it.
